item.title: Myanmar coup: Detained Aung San Suu Kyi faces charges
item.description: The elected civilian leader has not been heard from since she was detained on Monday.

item.title: Covid-19: Study showing Oxford vaccine slows virus spread 'superb' - Hancock
item.description: As results show the Oxford jab may cut transmission, the health secretary says it offers a "way out".

item.title: Golden Globes 2021: Three female directors make history in nominations
item.description: Three women are nominated for best director - the first time more than one has been shortlisted.

item.title: Covid: Australian MPs clash in hallway over misinformation
item.description: In a hallway confrontation, Tanya Plibersek accuses opponent Craig Kelly of spreading misinformation.

item.title: Eric Trump hits out at Scottish wealth discussion
item.description: MSPs will vote on a motion calling for an investigation into the former US president's business interests

item.title: Farmers' protest: Rihanna tweet angers Indian government
item.description: The singer and other celebrities tweeted in solidarity with farmers protesting against new laws.

item.title: Australian Open stars isolate after hotel Covid case
item.description: Up to 600 Australian Open players, officials and support staff will go into isolation - until they test negative - after a coronavirus case at a Melbourne hotel.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics: Playbook rules detailed to safeguard against coronavirus
item.description: Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics organisers publish a first set of rules aimed at ensuring coronavirus is controlled.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Missing hiker 'taken against will'
item.description: Esther Dingley last communicated with her partner on 22 November while on a solo trek in Spain.

item.title: Sinovac and Sinopharm - what do we know about the Chinese vaccines?
item.description: China has 16 vaccines in development, but those from Sinovac and Sinopharm are the front-runners.

item.title: Draghi asked to form new Italian coalition government
item.description: The former European Central Bank chief is asked by the president to form a new coalition government.

item.title: Mariah Carey sued by sister over 'vindictive' book
item.description: The US singer's older sibling wants $1.2m for distress caused by comments in her recent memoir.

item.title: The YouTuber and the school row over masturbation
item.description: What should teenage girls be taught about sex and when?

item.title: Influencers told not to use 'misleading' beauty filters
item.description: The Advertising Standards Authority ruling applies to brands and influencers on social media.

item.title: Haunting images of America's painful past
item.description: Rich Frishman has travelled the United States, documenting the vestiges of racial oppression that are all around us.

item.title: Solar energy empowers young women in Yemen
item.description: Ten women in Yemenâ€™s Abs district have built and now run a solar microgrid.

item.title: Cape cormorants: Caring for South Africa's chicks abandoned in wild
item.description: Rescuers come to the aid of hundreds of baby Cape cormorants abandoned by their parents.

item.title: Ancient mummies with golden tongues unearthed in Egypt
item.description: It is thought the dead were given the tongues 2,000 years ago so they could speak in the afterlife.

item.title: GameStop: Real Wolf of Wall Street warns 'you could lose it all'
item.description: Jordan Belfort says amateurs should "take their chips off the table" as shares in the retailer tumble.

item.title: 'I got my Florida school district to convert to electric buses'
item.description: Holly Thorpe's science fair project measured CO2 levels around school buses and led to the change.

item.title: The South African chefs fighting hunger with food waste
item.description: How hundreds of tonnes of food that would have gone to waste is used to feed the nation's poorest residents.

item.title: Which face mask or covering is best to wear?
item.description: Germany and Austria have changed their advice about which face covering to wear in public spaces.

item.title: Racial Impostor Syndrome: When you're made to feel like a fake
item.description: New York school student Arden Yum says ethnic minority children may not identify with the racial identity they were born with.

item.title: The migrant girl, 9, detained by US for 531 days and counting
item.description: The mother and daughter from El Salvador have narrowly evaded deportation "at least five times".

item.title: Golden Globes 2021: Six things to look out for in the nominations
item.description: The nominations will belatedly fire the starting gun for this year's Hollywood awards season.

item.title: India farmer protests: 'War-like fortification' to protect Delhi
item.description: Barricades of iron spikes, breeze blocks and barbed wire are in place to keep out striking farmers.

item.title: Australian Open: Stefanos Tsitsipas' family bond & the day he nearly drowned
item.description: Stefanos Tsitsipas is one of tennis' best young players. Behind the charisma & confidence lies a unique story of progression to the top.

item.title: Bebo chief reveals plan to take on Facebook and Twitter
item.description: Michael Birch sold Bebo for $850m in 2008, but now plans to revive it with a focus on profiles.

item.title: Obituary: Captain Sir Tom Moore, a hero who gave a nation hope
item.description: The Army veteran who raised millions for NHS charities during the coronavirus pandemic dies at 100.

item.title: Myanmar coup: What is happening and why?
item.description: Myanmar hit headlines around the world on Monday when its military seized control.

item.title: Is Russia targeting CIA spies with secret weapons?
item.description: Ex-CIA officer Marc Polymeropoulos believes he was targeted while on a visit to Moscow.

item.title: Jack Palladino: Private eye's photos used to track his suspected killers
item.description: Jack Palladino has died after a struggle with alleged robbers who tried to steal his camera.

item.title: 'We lost again in a horrible way' - how do you recover from a 9-0 thrashing... twice?
item.description: Southampton suffer two 9-0 defeats in 16 months - they recovered once, how do they do it again?

item.title: 'I might be pushing them a bit' - flattered DeChambeau welcomes proposed rule changes
item.description: US Open champion Bryson DeChambeau says he will find the best way to play under the rules of golf after welcoming new proposals that will hamper how far he can hit the ball.

item.title: LGBT+ History Month: The history of the Gay Games - the event that grew but stuck to its principles
item.description: The 11th Gay Games will take place in Hong Kong next year, four decades after a former US decathlete-turned-physician's dreams of a truly inclusive sporting event became reality.

item.title: Super Bowl 55: Can you name every Super Bowl winner since 2000?
item.description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers taking on the Kansas City Chiefs in Sunday night's Super Bowl - how many winners since 2000 can you name?

item.title: England to host Austria & Romania in rescheduled Euro 2020 warm-up games
item.description: England will play Austria and Romania in June in preparation for the rearranged Euro 2020.

item.title: 'I've lost enough money to these peanuts' - Kyrgios holds up play over umpire decision
item.description: Nick Kyrgios stops play for almost five minutes and calls the umpires "peanuts" in his victory at the Murray River Open.

item.title: Myanmar coup: Min Aung Hlaing, the general who seized power
item.description: Min Aung Hlaing rose through the ranks of the army to become commander-in-chief before seizing power.

item.title: Myanmar coup: Fitness instructor unwittingly films video as takeover unfolds
item.description: Recording her dance routine, Khing Hnin Wai had no idea she was filming a military takeover.

item.title: 'I was five when they snatched my father'
item.description: The coup has sent a chill through many in the country who grew up under decades of military rule.

item.title: Myanmar coup: How the military disrupted the internet
item.description: As the military took power, internet access was restricted in many parts of the country, but how was it done?

item.title: Military coup likely to damage Myanmar's economy
item.description: Businesses say the army's takeover has already put billions worth of foreign investment at risk.
